error.signature: Error response from daemon: Mounts denied

verdict.summary: Docker cannot mount the requested host path. The path may not be shared in Docker Desktop settings, or permissions are insufficient.

dead_ends.action: Running Docker as root to bypass mount permissions
dead_ends.why_fails: Security risk and doesn't fix the underlying sharing/path issue on Docker Desktop

workarounds.action: On macOS/Windows, add the host path to Docker Desktop file sharing settings
workarounds.how:
Docker Desktop > Settings > Resources > File Sharing.
Add the parent directory (e.g., /Users/yourname/projects) to the list.
Click 'Apply & Restart'.

On macOS with VirtioFS (default on newer versions), most paths under /Users are shared automatically. If using gRPC FUSE, you must explicitly add paths.

workarounds.action: Use a Docker volume instead of bind mount for better portability
workarounds.how:
# Create a named volume:
docker volume create mydata

# Use it instead of a bind mount:
docker run -v mydata:/app/data myimage

# In docker-compose.yml:
volumes:
  mydata:
services:
  app:
    volumes:
      - mydata:/app/data

frequently_confused_with.distinction: mount-denied means Docker cannot access the host path at all; volume-mount-permission-denied means the mount succeeds but file permissions inside the container are wrong.
